attribute.value:

For all data, added IPCC requested metadata

attribute.name: title
attribute.value: The data show monthly average total precipitation anomaly for the period (2020-2039) compared to present day (1980-1999) for SRES emissions scenario A1B

attribute.name: references
attribute.value:
Collins, W.D., et al., 2005: The Community Climate System Model, Version 3 Journal of Climate
Main website: http://www.ccsm.ucar.edu

attribute.name: comment
attribute.value:
This simulation was initiated from year 2000 of CCSM3 model run b30.030a and executed on hardware cheetah.ccs.ornl.gov. The input external forcings are ozone forcing : A1B.ozone.128x64_L18_1991-2100_c040528.nc aerosol optics : AerosolOptics_c040105.nc aerosol MMR : AerosolMass_V_128x256_clim_c031022.nc carbon scaling : carbonscaling_A1B_1990-2100_c040609.nc solar forcing : Fixed at 1366.5 W m-2 GHGs : ghg_ipcc_A1B_1870-2100_c040521.nc GHG loss rates : noaamisc.r8.nc volcanic forcing : none DMS emissions : DMS_emissions_128x256_clim_c040122.nc oxidants : oxid_128x256_L26_clim_c040112.nc SOx emissions : SOx_emissions_A1B_128x256_L2_1990-2100_c040608.nc Physical constants used for derived data: Lv (latent heat of evaporation): 2.501e6 J kg-1 Lf (latent heat of fusion ): 3.337e5 J kg-1 r[h2o] (density of water ): 1000 kg m-3 g2kg (grams to kilograms ): 1000 g kg-1
Integrations were performed by NCAR and CRIEPI with support and facilities provided by NSF, DOE, MEXT and ESC/JAMSTEC.

attribute.name: additional_note
attribute.value: Ensemble average created by strandwg on Fri Aug 22 13:34:00 MDT 2008

attribute.name: summary
attribute.value: Anomaly was calculated by subtracting the monthly average in the 20th Century Expiriment ensemble average (1980-1999) from the monthly average for (2020-2039) in the SRES scenario A1B ensemble average.

attribute.name: keywords_vocabulary
attribute.value: NASA/Global Change Master Directory (GCMD) Earth Science Keywords. Version 6.0.0.0.0

attribute.name: source
attribute.value: CCSM3.0, version beta19 (2004): atmosphere: CAM3.0, T85.

attribute.name: project
attribute.value: GIS Program, GIS Climate Change Scenarios Portal

attribute.name: license
attribute.value: The data and information contained in this report is intended for research purposes only. It is provided "as is" and without representations or warranties of any kind

attribute.name: program_info
attribute.value: The Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Program at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) is an interdisciplinary effort to foster collaborative science, spatial data interoperability, and knowledge sharing with GIS. The main goal of the GIS Program is to promote and support the use of GIS as both an analysis, and an infrastructure tool in atmospheric research and to address broader issues of spatial data management, interoperability, and geoinformatics within the geosciences. Working in collaboration with other NCAR strategic initiatives, divisions, and UCAR programs (such as Unidata, CDP, IMAGe, CGD, ISSE and RAL), we support variety of science projects at NCAR, make atmospheric data sets compatible with GIS tools, create bridges between atmospheric, geo- and social sciences, enable users to access, integrate and manage spatial information, and communicate science outcomes to the community of GIS users and the stakeholders.

The user assumes all risk as to the use of the data and/or information.
